Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Low-Cost 2D and 3D Millimeter Wave Image Sensors
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project includes a new, low-cost approach to 3D millimeter wave image sensors enabling non-destructive evaluation in construction, as well as other fields such as robotics, security, and quality control. Millimeter wave imaging uses human-safe, radio frequency signals to make high resolution images of objects that cannot be seen with conventional optical sensors. Because of their long wavelength, millimeter waves pass through many materials that are opaque to visible light, including common construction materials such as drywall, brick, tile, cement, and wood. For example, in the construction market, dramatic cost savings and faster, safer, and more accurate construction work could be achieved using millimeter wave imaging for structural evaluation as well as observing hidden utilities such as wiring and plumbing that should be avoided while drilling, and detecting hazards such as water leaks behind wall surfaces. This project will also provide entrepreneurial opportunity to a new generation of scholars/innovators as the technology matures toward commercial practice.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to advance the state of the art in millimeter wave imaging and enable low-cost, standalone 3D millimeter wave imagers. Prior work in a laboratory environment has demonstrated the promise of millimeter wave imaging for applications such as structural analysis in construction, however commercialization requires an image sensor that is fast, portable, low power, and low cost. This project will enable low cost hardware/software platforms for millimeter wave imaging using commercial chipsets with novel general purpose graphics processing unit (GPGPU)-accelerated image reconstruction algorithms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
ThruWave’s Phase I SBIR project (titled ‘Low-Cost 2D and 3D Millimeter Wave Image Sensors’) focused on the design and optimization of a low-cost, high-performance, 3D millimeter wave image sensor system and accompanying image reconstruction software. Human-safe millimeter waves have the useful property that they can pass through opaque materials, imaging scenes typically unavailable to traditional cameras, such as imaging items within sealed packages, or items otherwise hidden behind materials such as cardboard, paper, wood, drywall, etc. In addition, millimeter wave imaging can produce 3D images so the spatial configuration of objects can be observed. There is an exciting opportunity for commercialization in quality assurance and inventory management in logistics, e-commerce, and manufacturing. Our low-cost system could help to automate and improve quality control metrics and offset the large cost of human labor when it comes to monitoring inventory.

There were two primary goals over the course of the Phase I research effort. The first was designing and optimizing parameters and elements of the imaging system. We did this using a modeling and simulation framework we developed that allowed us to experiment with imaging system configurations. In designing the system, we had to balance image quality, image acquisition speed, and image processing speed, against hardware characteristics such as the number and orientation of antenna elements, and processor (FPGA + GPU) size and cost.

The second goal was establishing the feasibility of near-real-time image reconstruction algorithms using emerging GPU computing platforms, such as low-cost FPGA + GPU mobile processor combinations. We were successful in creating a novel image reconstruction software that is able to process 3D millimeter wave images in near-real-time. In addition, we have also developed image display software allowing the user to visualize the images in a multitude of ways including 3D point clouds and 2D ‘slices’ of the 3D dataset.

The successful completion of these two Phase I aims has paved the way for subsequent development of low-cost, high performance millimeter wave image sensor systems that are suitable for commercial applications.
